subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Need common abbreviation list
msgSnippet: Excellent. Thank you. This is exactly I wanted--an ASCII letter assignment for each QS letter that was grounded in modern linguistic notation. I m designing a
messageBody:
Excellent. Thank you. This is exactly I wanted--an ASCII letter
assignment for each QS letter that was grounded in modern linguistic
notation.

I'm designing a new font for QS. (I haven't mentioned it until now
because my progress is quite slow. I can't keep up with Paul.) One of
the issues I've faced is whether to use the same keyboard assignments
as existing fonts. Until now I was just planning to change assignments
for #20, #41-44, the name dot and angled brackets, but now I'm going
to use this list.

The only assignment I puzzled over, initially, was 'y' for #36, given
that 'V' is used in X-SAMPA. But then I guessed that since it's
probably the most frequently used letter, you reasoned that you'd like
to assign a lower-case ASCII letter for efficiency. What makes this
even more brilliant is that it leaves 'V' available for the alternate
letter-form for #36.

After arbitrarily assigning 'M' to the alternate letter for #23, the
remaining Latin letters are q, B, C, F, L and P. (I've dropped the
alternate letter-form for #8 for two reasons. First, my font is
intended for graphic design, and not to approximate handwriting.
Second, the QM refers only to "an allowable extension upward and
forward" for #8. It's not an alternate letter in the same sense as
those for #23 and #36.

For the name dot, I'd like to use the backquote: `. The only other
punctuation marks I'm willing to assign are the brackets '[' and ']',
for the angled brackets.

There are 10 ligatures that I want to include in my font, and only 6
remaining Latin letters. For now, I've made some provisional choices.
You can see what I'm currently thinking here:

http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/qs_proposal2.pdf

Anything in red is subject to change at the drop of a hat. Suggestions
are welcomed.

Ted


On Nov 18, 2007 10:42 AM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
>
>
> > But then I suppose a careful attempt to come up with single ASCII
> > characters to correspond to the 44 QS symbols based on X-SAMPA might
> > be difficult. I haven't tried yet.
>
> Here's one possibility. Deviations from X-SAMPA are given in parens.
>
> Pea p
> Bay b
> Tea t
> Day d
> Key k
> Gay g
> Thaw T
> They D
> Fee f
> Vie v
> See s
> Zoo z
> She S
> Jai Z
> Cheer c (X-SAMPA: tS)
> Jay J (X-SAMPA: dZ)
> Ye j
> Way w
> He h
> Why W
> Ing N
> May m
> No n
> Low l
> Roe r
> It I
> Eat i
> Et E
> Eight e (X-SAMPA: eI or EI)
> At a (X-SAMPA: left curly bracket)
> I Y (X-SAMPA: aI)
> Ah A
> Awe O
> Ox Q
> Oy R (as in Roy; X-SAMPA: OI)
> Utter y (X-SAMPA: @ or V)
> Out H (as in How; X-SAMPA: aU)
> Owe o (X-SAMPA: ou or @u or OU)
> Foot U
> OOze u
> Llan K
> Loch x
> Ax X (X-SAMPA: ks)
> Exam G (X-SAMPA: gz)
>
> Of course, some of the original X-SAMPA decisions are arbitrary too,
> notably Q and K (there's just nothing to be done about the fact
> that there are gobs of l-like letters in IPA and only one k-like letter).
>
>
> > And also Kirshenbaum notation: http://www.kirshenbaum.net/IPA/
>
> Kirsh has been mostly replaced by X-SAMPA.
>
>
> > Is there anyone else who'd like to see changes in the keyboard mappings?
>
> I would. However, there at least two caveats:
>
> 1) It would be a very considerable change to everyone who's used
> to the existing system (if not as drastic as changing from TO to QS!)
>
> 2) As I've hammered home over the past month, this is an IPA-ization
> of only some accents.
>
> --
> By Elbereth and Luthien the Fair, you shall cowan@...
> have neither the Ring nor me! --Frodo http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
>
